verses.text: He devoted his life to monastic philosophy; and although he received no instruction, he became, contrary to all expectation, so proficient in the learning and language of the Syrians, that he comprehended with ease the most abstruse theorems of philosophy.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:7
verses.text: His style of writing was so replete with splendid oratory and with richness and temperateness of thought that he surpassed the most approved writers of Greece.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:8
verses.text: If the works of these writers were to be translated into Syriac, or any other language, and divested, as it were, of the beauties of the Greek language, they would retain little of their original elegance and value.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:9
verses.text: The productions of Ephraim have not this disadvantage: they were translated into Greek during his life, and translations are even now being made, and yet they preserve much of their original force, so that his works are not less admired when read in Greek than when read in Syriac.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:10
verses.text: Basil, who was subsequently bishop of the metropolis of Cappadocia, was a great admirer of Ephraim, and was astonished at his erudition.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:11
verses.text: The opinion of Basil, who is universally confessed to have been the most eloquent man of his age, is a stronger testimony, I think, to the merit of Ephraim, than anything that could be indited to his praise.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:12
verses.text: It is said that he wrote three hundred thousand verses, and that he had many disciples who were zealously attached to his doctrines.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:13
verses.text: The most celebrated of his disciples were Abbas, Zenobius, Abraham, Maras, and Simeon, in whom the Syrians and whoever among them pursued accurate learning make a great boast.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:14
verses.text: Paulanas and Aranad are praised for their finished speech, although reported to have deviated from sound doctrine.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:15
verses.text: I am not ignorant that there were some very learned men who formerly flourished in Osroëne, as, for instance, Bardasanes, who devised a heresy designated by his name,  and Harmonius, his son.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:16
verses.text: It is related that this latter was deeply versed in Grecian erudition, and was the first to subdue his native tongue to meters and musical laws; these verses he delivered to the choirs, and even now the Syrians frequently sing, not the precise copies by Harmonius, but the same melodies.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:17
verses.text: For as Harmonius was not altogether free from the errors of his father, and entertained various opinions concerning the soul, the generation and destruction of the body, and the regeneration which are taught by the Greek philosophers, he introduced some of these sentiments into the lyrical songs which he composed.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:18
verses.text: When Ephraim perceived that the Syrians were charmed with the elegance of the diction and the rhythm of the melody, he became apprehensive, lest they should imbibe the same opinions; and therefore, although he was ignorant of Grecian learning, he applied himself to the understanding of the metres of Harmonius, and composed similar poems in accordance with the doctrines of the Church, and wrought also in sacred hymns and in the praises of passionless men.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:19
verses.text: From that period the Syrians sang the odes of Ephraim according to the law of the ode established by Harmonius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:20
verses.text: The execution of this work is alone sufficient to attest the natural endowments of Ephraim.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:21
verses.text: He was as celebrated for the good actions he performed as for the rigid course of discipline he pursued.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:22
verses.text: He was particularly fond of tranquillity.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:23
verses.text: He was so serious and so careful to avoid giving occasion to calumny, that he refrained from the very sight of women.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:24
verses.text: It is related that a female of careless life, who was either desirous of tempting him, or who had been bribed for the purpose, contrived on one occasion to meet him face to face, and fixed her eyes intently upon him; he rebuked her, and commanded her to look down upon the ground, "Wherefore should I obey your injunction," replied the woman; "for I was born not of the earth, but of you? It would be more just if you were to look down upon the earth whence you sprang, while I look upon you, as I was born of you".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:25
verses.text: Ephraim, astonished at the little woman, recorded the whole transaction in a book, which most Syrians regard as one of the best of his productions.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:26
verses.text: It is also said of him, that, although he was naturally prone to passion, he never exhibited angry feeling toward any one from the period of his embracing a monastic life.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:27
verses.text: It once happened that after he had, according to custom, been fasting several days, his attendant, in presenting some food to him, let fall the dish on which it was placed.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:28
verses.text: Ephraim, perceiving that he was overwhelmed with shame and terror, said to him, "Take courage; we will go to the food as the food does not come to us" and he immediately seated himself beside the fragments of the dish, and ate his supper.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:29
verses.text: What I am about to relate will suffice to show that he was totally exempt from the love of vainglory.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:30
verses.text: He was appointed bishop of some town, and attempts were made to convey him away for the purpose of ordaining him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:31
verses.text: As soon as he became aware of what was intended, he ran to the market-place, and showed himself as a madman by stepping in a disorderly way, dragging his clothes along, and eating in public.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:32
verses.text: Those who had come to carry him away to be their bishop, on seeing him in this state, believed that he was out of his mind, and departed; and he, meeting with an opportunity for effecting his escape, remained in concealment until another had been ordained in his place.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:33
verses.text: What I have now said concerning Ephraim must suffice, although his own countrymen relate many other anecdotes of him.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:34
verses.text: Yet his conduct on one occasion, shortly before his death, appears to me so worthy of remembrance that I shall record it here.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:35
verses.text: The city of Edessa being severely visited by famine, he quitted the solitary ceil in which he pursued philosophy, and rebuked the rich for permitting the poor to die around them, instead of imparting to them of their superfluities; and he represented to them by his philosophy, that the wealth which they were treasuring up so carefully would turn to their own condemnation, and to the ruin of the soul, which is of more value than all riches, and the body itself and all other values, and he proved that they were putting no estimate upon their souls, because of their actions.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:36
verses.text: The rich men, revering the man and his words, replied, "We are not intent upon hoarding our wealth, but we know of no one to whom we can confide the distribution of our goods, for all are prone to seek after lucre, and to betray the trust placed in them".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:37
verses.text: "What think you of me?" asked Ephraim.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:38
verses.text: On their admitting that they considered him an efficient, excellent, and good man, and worthy, and that he was exactly what his reputation confirmed, he offered to undertake the distribution of their alms.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:39
verses.text: As soon as he received their money, he had about three hundred beds fitted up in the public porches; and here he tended those who were ill and suffering from the effects of the famine, whether they were foreigners or natives of the surrounding country.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:40
verses.text: On the cessation of the famine he returned to the cell in which he had previously dwelt; and, after the lapse of a few days, he expired.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:41
verses.text: He attained no higher clerical degree than that of deacon, although he became no less famous for his virtue than those who are ordained to the priesthood and are admired for the conversation of a good life and for learning.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:42
verses.text: I have now given some account of the virtue of Ephraim.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:43
verses.text: It would require a more experienced hand than mine, to furnish a full description of his character and that of the other illustrious men who, about the same period, had devoted themselves to a life and career of philosophy; and for some things, it would require such a writer as he himself was.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:44
verses.text: The attempt is beyond my powers by reason of weakness of language, and ignorance of the men themselves and their exploits.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:45
verses.text: Some of them concealed themselves in the deserts.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:46
verses.text: Others, who lived in the intercourse of cities, strove to preserve a mean appearance, and to seem as if they differed in no respect from the multitude, working out their virtue, concealing a true estimate of themselves, that they might avoid the praises of others.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 16:47
verses.text: For as they were intent upon the exchange of future benefits, they made God alone the witness of their thoughts, and had no concern for outward glory.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 17:1
verses.text: Chapter XVII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 17:2
verses.text: —Transactions of that Period, and Progress of Christian Doctrine through the Joint Efforts of Emperors and Arch-Priests.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 17:3
verses.text: Those who presided over the churches at this period were noted for personal conduct, and, as might be expected, the people whom they governed were earnestly attached to the worship of Christ.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 17:4
verses.text: Religion daily progressed, by the zeal, virtue, and wonderful works of the priests, and of the ecclesiastical philosophers, who attracted the attention of the pagans, and led them to renounce their superstitions.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 17:5
verses.text: The emperors who then occupied the throne were as zealous as was their father in protecting the churches, and they granted honors and tax exemptions to the clergy, their children, and their slaves.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 17:6
verses.text: They confirmed the laws enacted by their father, and enforced new ones prohibiting the offering of sacrifice, the worship of images, or any other pagan observance.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 17:7
verses.text: They commanded that all temples, whether in cities or in the country, should be closed.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 17:8
verses.text: Some of these temples were presented to the churches, when either the ground they stood on or the materials for building were required.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 17:9
verses.text: The greatest possible care was bestowed upon the houses of prayer, those which had been defaced by time were repaired, and others were erected from the foundations in a style of extraordinary magnificence.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 17:10
verses.text: The church of Emesa is one most worthy to see and famous for its beauty.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 17:11
verses.text: The Jews were strictly forbidden to purchase a slave belonging to any other heresy than their own.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 17:12
verses.text: If they transgressed this law, the slave was confiscated  to the public; but if they administered to him the Jewish rite of circumcision, the penalties were death and total confiscation of property.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 17:13
verses.text: For, as the emperors were desirous of promoting by every means the spread of Christianity, they deemed it necessary to prevent the Jews from proselyting those whose ancestors were of another religion, and those who were holding the hope of professing Christianity were carefully reserved for the Church; for it was from the pagan multitudes that the Christian religion increased.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 18:1
verses.text: Chapter XVIII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 18:2
verses.text: —Concerning the Doctrines held by the Sons of Constantine.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 18:3
verses.text: Distinction between the Terms "Homoousios" and "Homoiousios".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 18:4
verses.text: Whence it came that Constantius quickly abandoned the Correct Faith.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 18:5
verses.text: The emperors  had, from the beginning, preserved their father's view about doctrine; for they both favored the Nicene form of belief.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 18:6
verses.text: Constans maintained these opinions till his death; Constantius held a similar view for some time; he, however, renounced his former sentiments when the term "consubstantial" was calumniated, yet he did not altogether refrain from confessing that the Son is of like substance with the Father.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 18:7
verses.text: The followers of Eusebius, and other bishops of the East, who were admired for their speech and life, made a distinction, as we know, between the term "consubstantial" (homoousios) and the expression "of like substance," which latter they designated by the term, "homoiousios".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 18:8
verses.text: They say that the term "consubstantial" (homoousios) properly belongs to corporeal beings, such as men and other animals, trees and plants, whose participation and origin is in like things; but that the term "homoiousios" appertains exclusively to incorporeal beings, such as God and the angels, of each one of whom a conception is formed according to his own peculiar substance.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 18:9
verses.text: The Emperor Constantius was deceived by this distinction; and although I am certain that he retained the same doctrines as those held by his father and brother, yet he adopted a change of phraseology, and, instead of using the term "homoousios," made use of the term "homoiousios".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 18:10
verses.text: The teachers to whom we have alluded maintained that it was necessary to be thus precise in the use of terms, and that otherwise we should be in danger of conceiving that to be a body which is incorporeal.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 18:11
verses.text: Many, however, regard this distinction as an absurdity, "for," say they, "the things which are conceived by the mind can be designated only by names derived from things which are seen; and there is no danger in the use of words, provided that there be no error about the idea.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 19:2
verses.text: —Further Particulars concerning the Term "Consubstantial".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 19:3
verses.text: Council of Ariminum, the Manner, Source, and Reason of its Convention.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 19:4
verses.text: It is not surprising that the Emperor Constantius was induced to adopt the use of the term "homoiousios," for it was admitted by many priests who conformed to the doctrines of the Nicaean council.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 19:5
verses.text: Many use the two words indifferently, to convey the same meaning.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 19:6
verses.text: Hence, it appears to me, that the Arians departed greatly from the truth when they affirmed that, after the council of Nicaea, many of the priests, among whom were Eusebius and Theognis, refused to admit that the Son is consubstantial with the Father, and that Constantine was in consequence so indignant, that he condemned them to banishment.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 19:7
verses.text: They say that it was afterwards revealed to his sister by a dream or a vision from God, that these bishops held orthodox doctrines and had suffered unjustly; and that the emperor thereupon recalled them, and demanded of them wherefore they had departed from the Nicene doctrines, since they had been participants in the document concerning the faith which had been there framed; and that they urged in reply that they had not assented to those doctrines from conviction, but from the fear that, if the disputes then existing were prolonged, the emperor, who was then just beginning to embrace Christianity, and who was yet unbaptized, might be impelled to return to Paganism, as seemed likely, and to persecute the Church.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 19:8
verses.text: They assert that Constantine was pleased with this defense, and determined upon convening another council; but that, being prevented by death from carrying his scheme into execution, the task devolved upon his eldest son, Constantius, to whom he represented that it would avail him nothing to be possessed of imperial power, unless he could establish uniformity of worship throughout his empire; and Constantius they say, at the instigation of his father, convened a council at Ariminum.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 19:9
verses.text: This story is easily seen to be a gross fabrication, for the council was convened during the consulate of Hypatius and Eusebius, and twenty-two years after Constantius had, on the death of his father, succeeded to the empire.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 19:10
verses.text: Now, during this interval of twenty-two years, many councils were held, in which debates were carried on concerning the terms "homoousios" and "homoiousios".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 19:11
verses.text: No one, it appears, ventured to deny that the Son is of like substance  with the Father, until Aëtius, by starting a contrary opinion, so offended the emperor that, in order to arrest the course of the heresy, he commanded the priests to assemble themselves together at Ariminum and at Seleucia.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 19:12
verses.text: Thus the true cause of this council being convened was not the command of Constantine,  but the question agitated by Aëtius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 19:13
verses.text: And this will become still more apparent by what we shall hereafter relate.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:1
verses.text: Chapter XX.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:2
verses.text: —Athanasius again reinstated by the Letter of Constantius, and receives his See.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:3
verses.text: The Arch-Priests of Antioch.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:4
verses.text: Question put by Constantius to Athanasius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:5
verses.text: The Praise of God in Hymns.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:6
verses.text: When Constans was apprised of what had been enacted at Sardica, he wrote  to his brother to request him to restore the followers of Athanasius and Paul to their own churches.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:7
verses.text: As Constantius seemed to hesitate, he wrote again, and threatened him with war, unless he would consent to receive the bishops.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:8
verses.text: Constantius, after conferring on the subject with the bishops of the East, judged that it would be foolish to excite on this account the horrors of civil war.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:9
verses.text: He therefore recalled Athanasius from Italy, and sent public carriages to convey him on his return homewards, and wrote several letters requesting his speedy return.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:10
verses.text: Athanasius, who was then residing at Aquilea, on receiving the letters of Constantius, repaired to Rome to take leave of Julius and his friends.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:11
verses.text: Julius parted from him with great demonstrations of friendship, and gave him a letter addressed to the clergy and people of Alexandria, in which he spoke of him as a wonderful man, deserving of renown by the numerous trials he had undergone, and congratulated the church of Alexandria on the return of so good a priest, and exhorted them to follow his doctrines.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:12
verses.text: He then proceeded to Antioch in Syria, where the emperor was then residing.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:13
verses.text: Leontius presided over the churches of that region; for after the flight of Eustathius, those who held heretical sentiments had seized the see of Antioch.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:14
verses.text: The first bishop they appointed was Euphronius; to him succeeded Placetus; and afterwards Stephen.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:15
verses.text: This latter was deposed as being unworthy of the dignity, and Leontius obtained the bishopric.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:16
verses.text: Athanasius avoided him as a heretic, and communed with those who were called Eustathians, who assembled in a private house.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:17
verses.text: Since he found that Constantius was well disposed, and agreeable, and it looked as if the emperor would restore his own church to him, Constantius, at the instigation of the leaders of the opposing heresy, replied as follows: "I am ready to perform all that I promised when I recalled you; but it is just that you should in return grant me a favor, and that is, that you yield one of the numerous churches which are under your sway to those who are averse to holding communion with you".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:18
verses.text: Athanasius replied: "O emperor, it is exceedingly just and necessary to obey your commands, and I will not gainsay, but as in the city of Antioch there are many who eschew communion between the heterodox and ourselves, I seek a like favor that one church may be conceded to us, and that we may assemble there in safety".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:19
verses.text: As the request of Athanasius appeared reasonable to the emperor, the heterodox deemed it more politic to keep quiet; for they reflected that their peculiar opinions could never gain any ground in Alexandria, on account of Athanasius, who was able both to retain those who held the same sentiments as himself, and lead those of contrary opinions; and that, moreover if they gave up one of the churches of Antioch, the Eustathians, who were very numerous, would assemble together, and then probably attempt innovations, since it would be possible for them without risk to retain those whom they held.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:20
verses.text: Besides, the heterodox perceived that, although the government of the churches was in their hands, all the clergy and people did not conform to their doctrines.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:21
verses.text: When they sang hymns to God, they were, according to custom, divided into choirs, and, at the end of the odes, each one declared what were his own peculiar sentiments.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:22
verses.text: Some offered praise to "the Father and the Son," regarding them as co-equal in glory; others glorified "The Father by the Son," to denote by the insertion of the preposition that they considered the Son to be inferior to the Father.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:23
verses.text: While these occurrences took place, Leontius, the bishop of the opposite faction, who then presided over the see of Antioch, did not dare to prohibit the singing of hymns to God which were in accordance with the tradition of the Nicaean Synod, for he feared to excite an insurrection of the people.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:24
verses.text: It is related, however, that he once raised his hand to his head, the hairs of which were quite white, and said, "When this snow is dissolved, there will be plenty of mud".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 20:25
verses.text: By this he intended to signify that, after his death, the different modes of singing hymns would give rise to great seditions, and that his successors would not show the same consideration to the people which he had manifested.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 21:1
verses.text: Chapter XXI.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 21:2
verses.text: —Letter of Constantius to the Egyptians in behalf of Athanasius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 21:3
verses.text: Synod of Jerusalem.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 21:4
verses.text: The emperor, on sending back  Athanasius to Egypt, wrote in his favor to the bishops and presbyters of that country, and to the people of the church of Alexandria; he testified to the integrity of his conduct and the virtue of his manners, and exhorted them to be of one mind, and to unite in prayer and service to God under his guidance.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 21:5
verses.text: He added that, if any evil-disposed persons should excite disturbances, they should receive the punishment awarded by the laws for such offenses.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 21:6
verses.text: He also commanded that the former decrees he had enacted against Athanasius, and those who were in communion with him, should be effaced from the public registers, and that his clergy should be admitted to the same exemptions they had previously enjoyed; and edicts to this effect were dispatched to the governors of Egypt and Libya.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 21:7
verses.text: Immediately on his arrival in Egypt, Athanasius displaced those whom he knew to be attached to Arianism, and placed the government of the Church and the confession of the Nicaean council in the hands of those whom he approved, and he exhorted them to hold to this with earnestness.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 21:8
verses.text: It was said at that time, that, when he was traveling through other countries, he effected the same change, if he happened to visit churches which were under the Arians.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 21:9
verses.text: He was certainly accused of having dared to perform the ceremony of ordination in cities where he had no right to do so.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 21:10
verses.text: But because he had effected his return, although his enemies were unwilling, and it did not seem that he could be easily cast under suspicion, in that he was honored with the friendship of the Emperor Constans, he was regarded with greater consideration than before.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 21:11
verses.text: Many bishops, who had previously been at enmity with him, received him into communion, particularly those of Palestine.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 21:12
verses.text: When he at that time visited these latter, they received him kindly.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 21:13
verses.text: They held a Synod at Jerusalem, and Maximus and the others wrote the following letter in his favor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 22:1
verses.text: Chapter XXII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 22:2
verses.text: —Epistle written by the Synod of Jerusalem in Favor of Athanasius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 22:3
verses.text: "The holy Synod assembled at Jerusalem, to the presbyters, deacons, and people of Egypt, Libya, and Alexandria, our beloved and most cherished brethren, greeting in the Lord.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 22:4
verses.text: "We can never, O beloved, return adequate thanks to God, the Creator of all things, for the wonderful works he has now accomplished, particularly for the blessings He has conferred on your churches by the restoration of Athanasius, your shepherd and lord, and our fellow-minister.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 22:5
verses.text: Who could have hoped to have ever seen this with his eyes, which now you are realizing in deed? But truly your prayers have been heard by the God of the universe who is concerned for His Church, and who has regarded your tears and complaint, and on this account has heard your requests.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 22:6
verses.text: For you were scattered abroad and rent like sheep without a pastor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 22:7
verses.text: Therefore, the true Shepherd, who from heaven watched over you, and who is concerned for His own sheep, has restored to you him whom you desired.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 22:8
verses.text: Behold, we do all things for the peace of the Church, and are influenced by love like yours.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 22:9
verses.text: Therefore we received and embraced your pastor, and, having held communion with you through him, we dispatch this address and our eucharistic prayers that you may know how we are united by the bond of love to him and you.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 22:10
verses.text: It is right that you should pray for the piety of the emperors most beloved of God, who having recognized your desire about him and his purity determined to restore him to you with every honor.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 22:11
verses.text: Receive him, then, with uplifted hands, and be zealous to send aloft the requisite eucharistic prayers in his behalf to the God who has conferred these benefits upon you; and may you ever rejoice with God, and glorify the Lord in Christ Jesus our Lord, by whom be glory to the Father throughout all ages, Amen".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 23:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIII.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 23:2
verses.text: —Valens and Ursacius, who belonged to the Arian Faction, confess to the Bishop of Rome that they had made False Charges against Athanasius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 23:3
verses.text: Such was the letter written by the Synod convened in Palestine.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 23:4
verses.text: Some time after Athanasius had the satisfaction of seeing the injustice of the sentence enacted against him by the council of Tyre publicly recognized.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 23:5
verses.text: Valens and Ursacius, who had been sent with Theognis and his followers to obtain information in Mareotis, as we before mentioned, concerning the holy cup which Ischyrion had accused Athanasius of having broken, wrote the following retraction to Julius, bishop of Rome:—      "Ursacius and Valens, to the most blessed Lord Pope Julius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 23:6
verses.text: "Since we previously, as is well known, made many various charges against Athanasius, the bishop, by our letters, and although we have been urged persistently by the epistles of your excellency in this matter which we publicly alleged and have not been able to give a reason for our accusation, therefore, we now confess to your excellency in the presence of all the presbyters, our brethren, that all that you have heard concerning the aforesaid Athanasius is utterly false and fictitious, and in every way foreign to his nature.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 23:7
verses.text: For this reason, we joyfully enter into communion with him, particularly as your piety in accordance with your implanted love of goodness has granted forgiveness to us for our error.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 23:8
verses.text: Moreover, we declare unto you that if the bishops of the East, or even Athanasius himself, should at any time malignantly summon us to judgment, we would not sever ourselves from your judgment and disposition about the case.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 23:9
verses.text: We now and ever shall anathematize, as we formerly did in the memorial which we presented at Milan, the heretic Arius and his followers, who say that there was a time, in which the Son existed not, and that Christ is from that which had no existence, and who deny that Christ was God and the Son of God before all ages.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 23:10
verses.text: We again protest, in our own handwriting, that we shall ever condemn the aforesaid Arian heresy, and its originators.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 23:11
verses.text: "I, Ursacius, sign this confession with my own signature.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 23:12
verses.text: In like manner also Valens".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 23:13
verses.text: This was the confession which they sent to Julius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 23:14
verses.text: It is also necessary to append to it their letter to Athanasius: it is as follows:—.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 24:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIV.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 24:2
verses.text: —Letter of Conciliation from Valens and Ursacius to the Great Athanasius.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 24:3
verses.text: Restoration of the Other Eastern Bishops to their own Sees.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 24:4
verses.text: Ejection of Macedonius again; and Accession of Paul to the See.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 24:5
verses.text: "The bishops, Ursacius and Valens, to Athanasius, our brother in the Lord.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 24:6
verses.text: "We take the opportunity of the departure of Museus, our brother and fellow-presbyter, who is going to your esteemed self, O beloved brother, to send you amplest greeting from Aquileia through him, and hope that our letter will find you in good health.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 24:7
verses.text: You will afford us great encouragement if you will write us a reply to this letter.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 24:8
verses.text: Know that we are at peace and in ecclesiastical communion with you".

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 24:9
verses.text: Athanasius therefore returned under such circumstances from the West to Egypt.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 24:10
verses.text: Paul, Marcellus, Asclepas, and Lucius, whom the edict of the emperor had returned from exile, received their own sees.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 24:11
verses.text: Immediately on the return of Paul to Constantinople Macedonius retired, and held church in private.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 24:12
verses.text: There was a great tumult at Ancyra on the deposition of Basil from the church there, and the reinstallation of Marcellus.

verses.name: Sozoman: Book III 24:13
verses.text: The other bishops were reinstated in their churches without difficulty.
